Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Autosomal dominant mutations in genes encoding protein components of sarcomere and its constituent myofibrillar proteins
70% have mutations in 2 genes, β-myosin heavy chain (MYH7) and myosin binding protein C (MYBPC3)

Clinical Issues.text: ~ 0.2% (i.e., 1:500) in general population
Palpitations, exertional dyspnea, atrial fibrillation, and sudden cardiac death

Macroscopic Features.text: Hypertrophy of left ventricle, asymmetrical or symmetrical
Classical: Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy (septum: Free wall thickness ratio > 1.3)
Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve and subaortic endocardial fibrosis

Microscopic Features.text: Diffuse myocyte hypertrophy
Myocyte disarray and myocytes with bizarre, disorganized myofibrillary architecture
Bizarre myocyte nuclei with nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, and hyperchromatism

Synonyms.text: Asymmetric (septal) hypertrophy, hypertrophic (muscular) subaortic stenosis, obstructive cardiomyopathy

Definitions.text: Common inherited cardiovascular disease characterized by left &/or right ventricular hypertrophy, usually asymmetric, involving the interventricular septum, causing impaired ventricle relaxation

Genetics.text: Autosomal dominant mutations in genes encoding protein components of the sarcomere and its constituent myofibrillar proteins
70% have mutations in either β-myosin heavy chain (MYH7) or myosin binding protein C (MYBPC3)
Troponin T (TNNT2) and several other genes each account for ≤ 5% of cases

Incidence.text: ~ 0.2% (1:500) in general population

Age.text: Can present at any age (including coincidentally at autopsy in elderly)

Gender.text: Is either under recognized or clinical diagnosis delayed, more frequently in women

Ethnicity.text: Is either under recognized or clinical diagnosis delayed, more frequently in African Americans

Presentation.text: Syncopal attacks, palpitations, exertional dyspnea, chest pain, atrial fibrillation, sudden cardiac death

Treatment.text: Endovascular alcohol septal ablation
Implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD)

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical septal myectomy

Drugs.text: β-blocker, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blocker

Prognosis.text: Most patients of HCM are asymptomatic
Mortality rates have ranged from < 1% to 3-6%
1st manifestation may be sudden cardiac death due to ventricular fibrillationYounger patients, particularly children, have a much higher mortality rate
sub_points: Younger patients, particularly children, have a much higher mortality rate

Echocardiography.text: Assess morphology of left ventricular hypertrophy, diastolic dysfunction
Dynamic left ventricular outflow obstruction (systolic anterior motion [SAM] of anterior mitral leaflet)

Stress Test.text: Assessment of functional capacity and response to therapy

Cardiac Magnetic Resonance.text: Magnitude of hypertrophy and anatomy of mitral valve

Coronary Arteriography.text: Rule out concomitant coronary artery disease

sub_points: Classical: Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy (septum: Free wall thickness ratio > 1.3)
Thickening of basal anterior septum
Symmetrical hypertrophic form accounts for 42%
Dilated or burned-out phase accounting for 10% of cases
Rare variants: Midventricular, apical patterns

General Features.text: Subaortic endocardial fibrosis ("mitral contact lesion")

Histologic Features.text: Myocyte hypertrophy, size > 40 μm (normal: 15 μm)
Myocyte disarray (> 20% of myocardium in ≥ 2 tissue blocks)
Myocytes with bizarre disorganized myofibrillary architecture
Bizarre myocyte nuclei, nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, and hyperchromatism
Interstitial and replacement fibrosis
Intramural coronary arteries show medial hypertrophy and luminal narrowing

Molecular Genetics.text: DNA sequencing for identification of mutations

Terminology.text: Increase in size (hypertrophy) and number (hyperplasia) of pancreatic islets

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infant of diabetic mother is by far the most common cause
Severe unremitting hypoglycemia in infants
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

Microscopic Features.text: Islet hypertrophy in infants > 2 months of age is defined as > 10% of islets being > 200 μm in diameter
Eosinophilic insulitis is pathognomonic for infants of diabetic mothers

Terminology.text: Benign tumor-like lesion of liver caused by hyperplastic response to localized vascular abnormality

Clinical Issues.text: Mostly incidental finding on imaging studies, most common in women

Macroscopic.text: Unencapsulated, well-circumscribed lesion with bulging cut surfaceNoncirrhotic background liver
sub_points: Noncirrhotic background liver

Microscopic.text: Localized nodular parenchyma with fibrous septa and stellate central scarSepta contain thick-walled vessels and mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate

Localized Abnormal Blood Flow.text: Steroids are not thought to play role

Presentation.text: Mostly incidental finding on imaging studies
More common in women
Normal liver biochemical tests

Prognosis.text: Benign lesion
Rupture and bleeding in rare cases

Periseptal hepatocytes may show positive copper staining due to cholestasis
Reticulin architecture is intact, but widened plates and focal loss can be seen at the periphery

Cytologic Features.text: Bland hepatocytes

Serum amyloid A (SAA): Typically negative, focally positive in few cases

Inflammatory Hepatocellular Adenoma.text: Naked unpaired arteries in parenchyma, sinusoidal dilatation, and lesional steatosis more common in adenoma
Ductular reaction, fibrous septa, and thick-walled arteries are more common in FNH
Diffuse immunoreactivity for serum amyloid A (SAA) and C-reactive protein (CRP) in most cases

Cirrhosis.text: Diffuse liver involvement by nodules surrounded by fibrous septa
Ductular reaction and inflammation may be present in fibrous septa
Bile ducts present except in ductopenic chronic biliary disease

Hepatocellular Carcinoma.text: Architectural changes like thick cell plates and frequent pseudoacinar structures
Cytologic atypia variable but often present
Ductular reaction not present in tumor

Nodular Regenerative Hyperplasia.text: By definition, fibrous septa are not present

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Nodular liver parenchyma with fibrous septa containing thick-walled arteries at periphery, bile ductular reaction, and mixed mononuclear inflammation

Terminology.text: Benign, reversible process characterized by hyperplastic follicles with secondary germinal centers

Clinical Issues.text: Enlarged lymph nodes, localized or widespread
± systemic symptoms: Fever, fatigue, weight loss
Age and duration are important clues for etiology
Lymph node size, location, and consistency can suggest likely etiologic agent

Microscopic.text: Numerous enlarged follicles, varying in size and shape, with occasional coalescence of follicles
Reactive follicles have central germinal centers and peripheral, sharply demarcated mantle zones
Germinal centers include predominantly centrocytes and centroblasts, few T lymphocytes and scattered histiocytes
Germinal centers: Usually organized into dark and light zones (a.k.a. polarization)

Ancillary Tests.text: Germinal center and mantle zone B cells express polytypic Igs and pan-B markers
Germinal center centrocytes and centroblasts are CD10(+), Bcl-6(+), and Bcl-2(-)
PolyclonalIGHgene rearrangements
No evidence of t(14;18)(q32;q21) orIGH-BCL2fusion sequences

Terminology.text: Nodular prostate enlargement due to cellular proliferation of prostatic glands and stroma associated with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)

Clinical Issues.text: A leading cause of morbidity in elderly men
Seen in 50% of men in their 50s, up to 80-90% of men in their 70s and 80s
Most common noncancerous cause of serum PSA elevation
Medical therapy is most frequently used approach
Surgery is more effective in terms of controlling LUTS
Without associated LUTS, features of glandular and stromal proliferation in needle biopsies shouldnotbe labeled as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)

Macroscopic.text: Hallmark of BPH is nodular prostatic enlargement
Hyperplastic nodules are mainly centered on proximal prostatic urethra involving transition zone and submucosal compartment

Microscopic.text: Epithelial predominant hyperplasia shows nodules composed of tightly clustered expanded ductal acinar elements
Stromal predominant hyperplasia composed of bland spindle cells with little cytoplasm and plump nuclei seen surrounding small blood vessels
Morphologic variants: Small glandular, cribriform, basal cell, leiomyomatous nodule, and phyllodes-type hyperplasia
Differential diagnosis for epithelial hyperplasia: Pseudohyperplastic variant of acinar carcinoma, atypical adenomatous hyperplasia
Differential diagnosis for stromal hyperplasia: Specialized stromal tumors of prostate, smooth muscle tumors, solitary fibrous tumors

Definitions.text: Nodular prostate enlargement due to cellular proliferation of prostatic glands and stroma associated with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)

sub_points: Undifferentiated mesenchyme, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells

Terminology.text: Cellular shrinkage with loss of cytoplasmic volume of prostatic ductal acinar unit and surrounding stroma

Clinical Issues.text: Frequency increases with age; more common after 6th decade of life
Remarkable in routine practice as morphologic mimicker of adenocarcinoma in prostate biopsy

Microscopic.text: Most commonly involves peripheral zone
All patterns of atrophy are characterized by acinar cells with scant cytoplasm producing higher nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
Glands contain crowded and hyperchromatic nuclei, imparting more basophilic appearance
Atrophy may be diffuse or widespread; linked to aging, androgen deprivation, and radiotherapy
Main morphologic types of focal atrophy include simple atrophy (SA), SA with cyst formation, postatrophic hyperplasia (PAH), and partial atrophy (PA)
SA consists of atrophic acini that are spaced relatively similarly to normal glands
SA with cyst formation shows cystic dilatation of atrophic acini
PAH consists of proliferative atrophic acini arranged in lobules, often surrounding central larger dilated duct
Unlike other forms of atrophy, PA contains relatively modest amount of pale or clear cytoplasm and has less crowded nuclei
Most are positive for basal cell markers; PA and PAH may have patchy or absent staining
Main differential diagnosis is prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features
PA is common reason for consultations of atypical glands concerning for cancer in biopsies

Definitions.text: Cellular shrinkage with loss of cytoplasmic volume of prostatic ductal acinar unit and surrounding stroma

Causes.text: Diffuse atrophy linked to aging, androgen deprivation, and radiotherapy
Secondary compression by benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) nodule, e.g., peripheral zone atrophy in BPH of transition zone
End result of severe chronic inflammation (postinflammatory atrophy)
Chronic local ischemia has also been suggested

Epidemiology.text: Very common; seen in 85% of prostates in autopsies of men > 40 years of age
Frequency increases with age; more common after 6th decade of life

Site.text: Commonly involves peripheral zone and, less frequently, central and transition zones

Presentation.text: Asymptomatic; incidental histologic finding
Remarkable in routine practice as morphologic mimicker of adenocarcinoma in prostate biopsy

Treatment.text: None

Prognosis.text: Benign course
Possible but very weak current evidence for atrophy as neoplastic precursor, suggested in postinflammatory atrophy with high proliferation index (proliferative inflammatory atrophy)

Histologic Features.text: Characterized by acinar cells with scant cytoplasm imparting higher nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
Maintains overall lobular configuration with angular or slit-like glands, occasionally with parent duct
Glands contain crowded and hyperchromatic nuclei, imparting more basophilic appearance
Since secretory cells have minimal to no cytoplasm, they resemble basal cells and impart single-cell type appearance
Glands may very rarely contain intraluminal mucin and crystalloids
Surrounding stroma with variable amount of fibrosis
Chronic inflammation may be seen in association with atrophic acini

Terminology.text: Irreversible myocardial damage caused by prolonged ischemia, resulting from sustained imbalance of perfusion, supply, and demand

Clinical Issues.text: Complications: AcuteRupture of myocardium (tamponade, acquired ventricular septal defect, ruptured papillary muscle)
sub_points: Rupture of myocardium (tamponade, acquired ventricular septal defect, ruptured papillary muscle)

Clinical Issues.text: Complications: Long termIschemic dilated cardiomyopathyVentricular true aneurysms (often with mural thrombus)
sub_points: Ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy
Ventricular true aneurysms (often with mural thrombus)

Macroscopic Features.text: 12-24 hours: No changes or subtle mottling
7-10 days: Grossly softened and depressed with more prominent hyperemic edges
3-8 weeks: Grayish-white scar begins to form at edges and progresses to center

Microscopic Features.text: 1-3 days: Coagulative necrosis with loss of nuclei, contraction bands, and heavy neutrophilic infiltration
3-7 days: Myocyte loss, karyorrhexis of neutrophils ("nuclear dust"), early phagocytosis by macrophages at infarct border
10-14 days: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and fibroblast infiltration
2-8 weeks: Increased collagen deposition with decreased cellularity

Synonyms.text: Myocardial ischemia, heart attack, acute coronary syndrome

Definitions.text: Myocardial infarction can be defined as irreversible myocardial muscle damage caused by prolonged ischemia, resulting from sustained imbalance of perfusion, supply, and demand

Nonatherosclerotic Coronary Disease.text: Coronary artery embolus (such as from endocarditis)

Other Causes of Mismatched Perfusion and.text: Left ventricular hypertrophy (cardiomyopathy, hypertensive heart disease)
Cardiac arrest (from nonischemic causes)Metabolic, neurogenic, arrhythmia
sub_points: Metabolic, neurogenic, arrhythmia

Other Causes of Mismatched Perfusion and.text: Impaired oxygen delivery (respiratory failure, severe anemia)

Incidence.text: Annual incidence of new myocardial infarction in USA has been estimated at 610,000 cases
Recurrent myocardial infarction accounts for 325,000 additional episodes

Age.text: Average: 64.5 years for men and 70.3 years for women

Gender.text: Women thought to be "protected" from coronary atherosclerosis in their reproductive years

Ethnicity.text: Prevalence is highest in developed nations, presumably due to comparatively high-calorie diet, more sedentary lifestyle, and longer life expectancy

Echocardiography.text: Assesses myocardial perfusion and microvascular obstruction (coronary flow reserve)

Radionucleotide Imaging.text: Commonly used to assess perfusion and viability

General Features.text: In initial few minutes to hours (up to 8-12 hours), there is no grossly apparent abnormality

Thereafter12-24 hours: No change or subtle mottling and regional stiffness1-3 days: Mottling with yellow-tan center3-7 days: Yellow-tan center with hyperemic edges7-10 days: Grossly softened and depressed with more prominent hyperemic edges10-14 days: Edges become more gray in color3-8 weeks: Grayish-white scar begins to form at edges and progresses to center8-12 weeks: Grayish-white scar with early remodeling (wall thinning and chamber dilatation)
sub_points: 12-24 hours: No change or subtle mottling and regional stiffness
1-3 days: Mottling with yellow-tan center
3-7 days: Yellow-tan center with hyperemic edges
7-10 days: Grossly softened and depressed with more prominent hyperemic edges
10-14 days: Edges become more gray in color
3-8 weeks: Grayish-white scar begins to form at edges and progresses to center
8-12 weeks: Grayish-white scar with early remodeling (wall thinning and chamber dilatation)

Hemorrhagic Infarct.text: After revascularization (durable or failed), restoration of blood flow to damaged tissue may result in hemorrhagic infarctionDark red-brown in color due to hemorrhage into ischemic tissues
sub_points: Dark red-brown in color due to hemorrhage into ischemic tissues

Vital Staining of Fresh Heart Tissue (Au.text: Triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) or nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT) dye testRedox indicator catalyzed by dehydrogenase enzymes in viable myocardium (but not infarcted myocardium)TTC will stain viable myocardium brick red (infarcted myocardium will remain unchanged)NBT will stain viable myocardium dark blue-purple (infarcted myocardium will remain unchanged)
sub_points: Redox indicator catalyzed by dehydrogenase enzymes in viable myocardium (but not infarcted myocardium)
TTC will stain viable myocardium brick red (infarcted myocardium will remain unchanged)
NBT will stain viable myocardium dark blue-purple (infarcted myocardium will remain unchanged)

Histologic Features.text: After 4 hours (variable), myocytes may appear wavy and elongated, interstitial edema

Within 24 hours, interstitial edema, focal hemorrhage, myocyte contraction bands, and infiltration of neutrophils (margination)Staining for C4d may be positive in acutely ischemic myocytes due to complement activation
sub_points: Staining for C4d may be positive in acutely ischemic myocytes due to complement activation

Histologic Features.text: 1-3 days: Coagulative necrosis with loss of nuclei, contraction bands, and heavy neutrophilic infiltration
3-7 days: Myocyte loss, karyorrhexis of neutrophils ("nuclear dust"), early phagocytosis by macrophages at infarct border
7-10 days: Well-developed phagocytosis with distended macrophages, granulation tissue at infarct border
10-14 days: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and fibroblast infiltration
2-8 weeks: Increased collagen deposition with decreased cellularity
> 2 months: Dense collagenous scar
Caveat: This sequence of changes assumes no revascularization (no reversal of ischemia)Spontaneous or interventional reperfusion must be taken into account
sub_points: Spontaneous or interventional reperfusion must be taken into account

Histologic Features.text: Reperfusion injury (after revascularization)Prominent coagulative necrosisMarked erythrocyte extravasation/hemorrhageSmall vessels may show small thrombi or atheroemboli
sub_points: Prominent coagulative necrosis
Marked erythrocyte extravasation/hemorrhage
Small vessels may show small thrombi or atheroemboli

Immunohistochemistry.text: C4d, C9: Positive staining in necrotic myocardium
cTnT: Negative staining in necrotic myocardium

Terminology.text: Ischemic insult to splenic parenchyma secondary to vascular occlusion or disruption

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Splenic infarction represents presentation, natural history, or complication of some underlying disease processArterial thromboembolism or traumaSplenic red pulp occlusionHypercoagulable states
sub_points: Arterial thromboembolism or trauma
Splenic red pulp occlusion
Hypercoagulable states

Clinical Issues.text: Symptoms depend on size of infarct
Left-sided upper abdominal pain, which may radiate to left shoulder tip
Splenic rupture may occur in large lesions and present as acute abdomen

Macroscopic Features.text: Typically wedge-shaped
Becomes better demarcated over time

Microscopic Features.text: Temporal progression of coagulative necrosis leading to repair and eventual fibrosis
May see hemosiderin, serositis, organizing thrombi

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Evaluation of underlying pathologic conditionThromboembolism, sickle cell disease, myeloproliferative neoplasms, vasculitis, sepsis
sub_points: Thromboembolism, sickle cell disease, myeloproliferative neoplasms, vasculitis, sepsis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Exclusion of lesions that may mimic infarctionNecrotizing granulomas, metastatic malignancy
sub_points: Necrotizing granulomas, metastatic malignancy

Definitions.text: Ischemic insult to splenic parenchyma secondary to vascular occlusion or disruptionCessation of blood supply results from wide variety of underlying pathologic conditionsCoagulative necrosis and eventual fibrosis develop in region of affected circulation
sub_points: Cessation of blood supply results from wide variety of underlying pathologic conditions
Coagulative necrosis and eventual fibrosis develop in region of affected circulation

Pathogenesis.text: Ischemic coagulative necrosisNecrosis, inflammation, and repair sequence parallel responses in other organsNecrotic tissue elicits influx of neutrophilsMacrophages increase to remove necrotic tissueFibroblasts proliferate and produce collagen to form scar tissueDuration of healing process may be longer for larger lesions
sub_points: Necrosis, inflammation, and repair sequence parallel responses in other organsNecrotic tissue elicits influx of neutrophilsMacrophages increase to remove necrotic tissueFibroblasts proliferate and produce collagen to form scar tissueDuration of healing process may be longer for larger lesions

Macrophages increase to remove necrotic tissue
Fibroblasts proliferate and produce collagen to form scar tissue
Duration of healing process may be longer for larger lesions

Presentation.text: Symptoms depend on size of infarct
Small infarcts are often clinically silent
Large infarcts present with left-sided upper abdominal pain
If diaphragmatic peritoneum becomes inflamed, pain may radiate to left shoulder tip or cause pleuritic chest pain
Infarcts due to embolic etiologies are commonly associated with fever
Leukocytosis and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels are common
Splenic rupture may occur in large lesions and present as acute abdomen

Ultrasonographic Findings.text: May aid in differentiating acute event (hypoechoic) from remote infarction (hyperechoic)
Visualization of infarct evolution to abscess

MR Findings.text: Well-defined lesions that are better visualized with delayed contrast-enhanced images
Capsular rim sign may be present due to capsular blood supply at edge of lesion
High-signal intensity on T1-weighted images if hematoma develops
Hypointense signal on T1- and T2-weighted images in old healed infarcts
Mesenteric vasculature may also be evaluated

CT Findings.text: Well-defined area of decreased attenuation within splenic parenchyma without contrast enhancement

Visceral Angiography.text: Useful when splenic arterial aneurysm or other vascular etiology/anomaly is suspected

Size and Weight.text: Variable based on size of infarct and underlying etiology
Small infarcts may not affect overall organ weight or size
Massive infarcts result in extensive scarring, decreased size, and functional hyposplenism (e.g., sickle cell disease)
Multifocal infarction as a result of certain disease states may present as splenomegaly due to underlying disease (e.g., myeloproliferative neoplasms, chronic congestion)

Infarct Morphology.text: Typically wedge-shaped with occluded artery at infarct apex and capsule forming the base
Volume of infarct increases in size according to vascular distribution
Infarct extends toward periphery, often involving capsule
Capsule overlying infarct may develop fibrinous or purulent exudate
Depending on etiology, infarcted area may be solitary or multiple, or may involve entire spleen
Although uncommon, parenchymal disruption in extensive lesions may be great enough to result in rupture

Temporal Evolution of Infarct.text: Gross appearance of infarct depends on length of time between ischemic event and splenectomy
Days 1-3 post infarctionInfarct is initially pale compared to surrounding parenchymaLesional boundaries gradually become more distinct
sub_points: Infarct is initially pale compared to surrounding parenchyma
Lesional boundaries gradually become more distinct

Temporal Evolution of Infarct.text: Days 3-7 post infarctionAffected tissue appears tan and soft as necrosis and inflammatory reaction ensueHyperemic rim is visible after several days as congestion and small amount of hemorrhage occur at viable/nonviable tissue interfaceHeight of necroinflammatory process may correlate with clinical presentation of splenic rupture
sub_points: Affected tissue appears tan and soft as necrosis and inflammatory reaction ensue
Hyperemic rim is visible after several days as congestion and small amount of hemorrhage occur at viable/nonviable tissue interface
Height of necroinflammatory process may correlate with clinical presentation of splenic rupture

Temporal Evolution of Infarct.text: Days 7 and beyond post infarctionMargins become better defined as lesion maturesInfarct turns pale yellow and firm as fibroblasts replace necrotic tissue to form scar
sub_points: Margins become better defined as lesion matures
Infarct turns pale yellow and firm as fibroblasts replace necrotic tissue to form scar

sub_points: Infarcted area becomes well delineated from surrounding viable parenchyma as lesion ages
In larger infarcts, organizing thrombi may be identified in splenic artery or its branches
When involved, capsule becomes inflamed with neutrophils, and surface may contain fibrinopurulent exudate (e.g., serositis)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Sharply demarcated, wedge-shaped area corresponding to vascular distribution

Macroscopic and microscopic features of infarct follow temporal sequence of coagulative necrosis and tissue repairInfarct is initially pale with corresponding tissue necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration (1-3 days post infarction)Lesion softens and develops hyperemic rim as tissue necrosis continues and macrophage activity peaks (3-7 days post infarction)Infarct becomes well defined and progressively firm as fibroblasts repair area of necrosis and scar develops (≥ 7 days post infarction)

Lesion softens and develops hyperemic rim as tissue necrosis continues and macrophage activity peaks (3-7 days post infarction)
Infarct becomes well defined and progressively firm as fibroblasts repair area of necrosis and scar develops (≥ 7 days post infarction)

Definitions.text: Loss of blood supply, and hence oxygen and nutrients, to a given area of brain due to blood vessel occlusion, resulting in tissue necrosis

Nonmodifiable Risk Factors.text: Race (lower risk for white North Americans/Europeans), family history

Treatable Risk Factors.text: Lipid disorders (high total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein [LDL])
Smoking, diabetes mellitus, obesity (relatively small risk after correction of other problems)
Alcoholism (low intake decreases risk, high intake increases risk)

Definitions.text: Lesions of breast characterized by acute, chronic, or granulomatous inflammation

Conditions.text: Acute mastitis/breast abscess, subareolar abscess, duct ectasia, lymphocytic mastitis, granulomatous mastitis

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Usually occurs in lactating women due to abrasion or crack in nipple resulting from nursingLeads to entry of bacteria followed by acute inflammation and eventually abscess formationNonlactational causes of acute mastitis are rare and often associated with smokingCommon organisms that cause acute mastitis:Staphylococcus aureus,Staphylococcus epidermidis,anaerobicStreptococcus,Bacteroides
sub_points: Leads to entry of bacteria followed by acute inflammation and eventually abscess formation
Nonlactational causes of acute mastitis are rare and often associated with smoking
Common organisms that cause acute mastitis:Staphylococcus aureus,Staphylococcus epidermidis,anaerobicStreptococcus,Bacteroides

Clinical Presentation.text: Breast swelling, redness, and warmth with feverLymphadenopathy may also be present
sub_points: Lymphadenopathy may also be present

Treatment.text: Managed medically or with incision and drainage

Cytopathology.text: Aspirate of breast abscesses can be thick yellowish green and purulent
In acute phase, marked acute inflammation ± necrotic cellular debris in background
In chronic phase, granulation tissue, and histiocytic and chronic inflammatory infiltration including multinucleated foreign body giant cells can be present
Few clusters and single ductal and mesenchymal cells ± reactive atypia with enlarged and prominent nucleus and mitotic figures

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts leads to keratin pluggingEventually results in duct rupture with extrusion of keratin and intense inflammatory reaction to keratinTobacco use can result in vitamin A deficiency and abnormal squamous metaplasia that can lead to subareolar abscess
sub_points: Eventually results in duct rupture with extrusion of keratin and intense inflammatory reaction to keratin
Tobacco use can result in vitamin A deficiency and abnormal squamous metaplasia that can lead to subareolar abscess

Clinical Presentation.text: Painful erythematous subareolar massIn late stages, fistulous tracks can open at edge of areola
sub_points: In late stages, fistulous tracks can open at edge of areola

Treatment.text: Can recur with incision and drainage; surgical removal of keratin-producing epithelium may be necessary

Cytopathology.text: Marked acute inflammation associated with many squamous cells, including anucleated squames or nucleated squamous cells
Multinucleated giant cells with engulfed keratinous material and squames in cytoplasm are characteristic
Granulation tissue, chronic inflammation, epithelioid, and foamy histiocytes can be present in longstanding lesions
Reactive changes in few clusters of ductal and squamous cells with enlarged nucleus and prominent nucleolus can mimic malignant cells

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Age-related weakness of walls of large ducts, resulting in ectasia of ductsDucts are filled with "cheesy" secretory materialDucts can rupture, resulting in intense inflammatory reaction to extravasated lipids
sub_points: Ducts are filled with "cheesy" secretory material

Clinical Presentation.text: Palpable, ill-defined subareolar mass that may be attached to skin and nipple; thick nipple dischargeUsually not associated with pain or redness
sub_points: Usually not associated with pain or redness

Treatment.text: No treatment is necessary if carcinoma is excluded

Cytopathology.text: Thick, "cheesy" material showing amorphous granular debris, often with cholesterol clefts and calcifications
Few clusters of ductal epithelial cells ± reactive changes associated with lymphocytes, plasma cells, lipofuscin-containing histiocytes referred to as ochrocytes, and multinucleated giant cells

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Can be sporadic or associated with autoimmune diseases, such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, Hashimoto thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis

Cytopathology.text: Few clusters of benign ductal epithelial cells associated with many lymphocytes

Idiopathic granulomatous mastitis: Excisional biopsy is curative; if inflammation persists, corticosteroids may be used

Cytopathology.text: Granulomas composed of epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells ± central necrosis or microabscesses

Silicone mastitis: Silicone may be dissolved in preparations leaving empty spacesIf not dissolved, appears as homogeneous, faintly yellow or blue, retractile nonbirefringent material in smearsAbundant histiocytes with vacuoles, multinucleated giant cells often with asteroid bodies may be seen
sub_points: If not dissolved, appears as homogeneous, faintly yellow or blue, retractile nonbirefringent material in smears

Carcinoma.text: Clinical presentation of subareolar mass in subareolar abscess or duct ectasia can mimic malignant lesion
Abundant clusters and single atypical cells in carcinoma unlike few clusters of ductal cells ± reactive atypia; highly atypical cells are sparse in inflammatory lesions
Breast cancers are generally not associated with marked acute inflammation

Lymphoma.text: Entities such as duct ectasia or lymphocytic mastitis are generally associated with mild to moderate infiltration of small lymphocytes, including histiocytes and plasma cells, unlike lymphoma which shows abundant lymphoid cells proven to be clonal

Inflammatory Breast Carcinoma.text: Obstruction of dermal lymphatics by tumor cells causes erythema and edema of breast, which can mimic acute mastitis/breast abscess
Usually not noted in lactational period, unlike acute mastitis or breast abscess; tissue biopsy and skin punch biopsy may be needed for distinction

Pathogenesis.text: Ischemic or toxic insult to tubular epithelium

Tubular injury and dysfunctionAltered epithelial transport results in reduction of resorption of NaClIncreased delivery of NaCl to macula densa in distal tubule activates tubuloglomerular feedback, thereby reducing glomerular filtration rate (GFR)Loss of tubular epithelial adhesion allows leak of glomerular filtrate into interstitium, reducing effective GFRExfoliated epithelium, increased tubular sodium, and Tamm-Horsfall protein combine to form luminal casts that obstruct flow
sub_points: Altered epithelial transport results in reduction of resorption of NaCl
Increased delivery of NaCl to macula densa in distal tubule activates tubuloglomerular feedback, thereby reducing glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
Loss of tubular epithelial adhesion allows leak of glomerular filtrate into interstitium, reducing effective GFR
Exfoliated epithelium, increased tubular sodium, and Tamm-Horsfall protein combine to form luminal casts that obstruct flow

Terminology.text: Pathologic definition of bronchopneumonia based on anatomic distribution of acute inflammatory changes
Distribution can be appreciated grossly as patchy foci of airway-centered consolidation with intervening areas of normal lung parenchyma (lobular distribution)
Lobular pattern is in contrast to lobar pneumonia (consolidation of an entire lobe)
Pneumonia is classified by specific etiologic agent

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Most often result of inhalation of microorganisms or aspiration
A preceding viral pneumonia increases susceptibility to secondary infection (bronchopneumonia)
Nosocomial pneumonia is leading cause of death from hospital-acquired infection
Gram-negative organisms predominate in ICU-acquired infections and ventilator-associated pneumonia

Macroscopic Features.text: May involve 1 or multiple lobes and is frequently bilateral
Most pronounced changes often in basilar regions

Microscopic Features.text: Airway-centered acute inflammation with contiguous involvement of peribronchial/peribronchiolar alveolated parenchyma
Focal or extensive organization may be present

Pathogenesis.text: In most circumstances, pathologic entity of bronchopneumonia is result of inhalation and aspiration
Endotracheal tube placement further compromises host defenses by impairing mucociliary function, injuring mucosa, and allowing secretions to pool
More likely in patients with other comorbidities
More common in patients with an impaired immune response (due to immunosuppressive medications, underlying immunodeficiency disease, or critical illness)
More common with a large inoculum (such as occurs with massive aspiration)
More common in patients with genetic differences, which are a focus of ongoing research
A preceding viral pneumonia increases susceptibility to bacterial pneumonia

Clinical Issues.text: Chronic progressive disease leading to permanent loss of pancreatic function
Steatorrhea
Diabetes mellitus
Weight loss

Islets of Langerhans usually preserved

Clinical Issues.text: Most common cause of heart failure overall and 2nd most common etiology of heart failure in transplantation
5-year survival post transplant (> 70%) is lower than for nonischemic cardiomyopathy but higher than for congenital heart disease or valvular cardiomyopathy
Metabolic risk factors that increase risk for CAD are also independent risk factors for post-transplant mortality and decreased 5-year survival

Macroscopic Features.text: Large areas of fibrosis are often present and may be subendocardial or transmural, consistent with healed myocardial infarctionsDistribution corresponds to coronary artery lesions
sub_points: Distribution corresponds to coronary artery lesions

Macroscopic Features.text: Usually multifocal obstruction of multiple coronary arteriesPathologic exam typically overestimates extent of stenosis due to remodeling of entire arterial wall and collapse of arterial lumen
sub_points: Pathologic exam typically overestimates extent of stenosis due to remodeling of entire arterial wall and collapse of arterial lumen

Microscopic Features.text: In areas of old myocardial infarction, fibrosis replaces myocytes
Myocytes immediately subjacent to endocardium are typically spared due to oxygen supply received from ventricular blood
Patchy interstitial or replacement fibrosis and myocyte hypertrophy are often seen but not specific

Synonyms.text: Ischemic cardiomyopathy, coronary artery disease (CAD), coronary heart disease (CHD)

Incidence.text: Most common cause of heart failure overall and 2nd most common etiology in transplantation
Leading cause of death worldwide
Mortality rates are falling in many economically developed countries due to advances in medical treatment and changes in risk factors

Age.text: Typically presents in middle-aged to older adults
Incidence increases with age

Gender.text: More common in males overall but risk increases for women after menopause

Presentation.text: "Silent" (asymptomatic) ischemia commonly precedes presentation of CAD

Prognosis.text: 5-year survival post transplant (> 70%) is lower than for nonischemic cardiomyopathy but higher than for congenital heart disease or valvular cardiomyopathy

General Features.text: Effect of formalin perfusion of lung on evaluation of pulmonary edema has long been debatedCutting lungs in a fresh state enhances appreciation of pulmonary edema and might be appropriate in some circumstances and is favored by some pathologistsHowever, perfusion of lung allows for better overall appreciation of many other pathologic processes such as infection, parenchymal disease, and malignancy (many of which coexist in a hospital autopsy population), and perfusion is therefore recommendedEven with perfusion, it is still possible to satisfactorily document pulmonary edema by observation, pre-perfusion lung weights, and microscopic sections

However, perfusion of lung allows for better overall appreciation of many other pathologic processes such as infection, parenchymal disease, and malignancy (many of which coexist in a hospital autopsy population), and perfusion is therefore recommended
Even with perfusion, it is still possible to satisfactorily document pulmonary edema by observation, pre-perfusion lung weights, and microscopic sections

Internal Examination.text: Cardiac disease is the major cause of nonpermeability pulmonary edemaSpecial attention should be paid to examination of the 4 heart chambers, cardiac valves, coronary vessels, and major vessels for any abnormality

Internal Examination.text: Renal disease or renal artery stenosis can also cause noncardiogenic, nonpermeability pulmonary edema

Organ Examination.text: Increased lung weights are a sensitive indicator of pulmonary disease and, in absence of another etiology such as infection or malignancy, reflect severity of fluid accumulation within lung
Prominent interstitial markings are often present on pleural surface and reflect accumulation of fluid within lobular interstitium

Sectioning of unfixed lung will result in exudation of fluid from cut surfaceAssuming no other underlying pulmonary disease or longstanding cardiac disease resulting in chronic passive congestion, lungs in cardiogenic and noncardiogenic, nonpermeability pulmonary edema are fairly compliantBy contrast, lungs with evolving diffuse alveolar damage are airless and firm

Organ Examination.text: Presence of frothy fluid exuding into trachea and bronchi prior to fixation is another indication of pulmonary edema

Terminology.text: Shock: Inability to meet cellular metabolic requirements due to inadequate circulating blood or plasma volume
MODS: Physiologic dysfunction of ≥ 2 organ or physiologic systems not directly related to primary cause of shock
SIRS: Systemic activation of innate immune response, regardless of cause
Sepsis: Probable or documented infection plus SIRS manifestations

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Shock: Hypovolemic, cardiogenic, systemic inflammation
SIRS: Sepsis, massive tissue injury, metabolic derangements, malignancy, neurologic trauma

Macroscopic Features.text: Evidence of specific cause of shock
Macroscopic stigmata of shock: e.g., diffuse petechia, pallor, edema, serosal effusions, "nutmeg" liver

Microscopic Features.text: Shock: Diffuse vascular congestion, hemorrhage, fibrin thrombi of microvasculature involving any organ system
Sepsis: Evidence of primary infection, septic emboli to any organ, widespread bacterial overgrowth
Microscopic stigmata of shock: e.g., subendocardial demand ischemia, diffuse alveolar damage, hepatic centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, acute tubular necrosis

Synonyms.text: MODS: Multi-organ failure, multiple systems organ failure

Definitions.text: Shock: Inability to meet cellular metabolic requirements due to global hypoperfusion from inadequate circulating blood or plasma volume

MODS: Physiologic dysfunction of ≥ 2 organ or physiologic systems not directly related to primary cause of shocke.g., acute tubular injury and coagulopathy following cardiogenic shock due to acute myocardial infarction
sub_points: e.g., acute tubular injury and coagulopathy following cardiogenic shock due to acute myocardial infarction

Definitions.text: SIRS: Systemic activation of innate immune response, regardless of cause, clinically manifested as 2 or more of the followingTemperature > 38°C or < 36°C; heart rate (HR) > 90 beats/min; hyperventilation (respiratory rate > 20 breaths/min or PaCO₂ < 32mmHg); white blood cell (WBC) count > 12,000/μL or < 4,000/μL or 10% bands
sub_points: Temperature > 38°C or < 36°C; heart rate (HR) > 90 beats/min; hyperventilation (respiratory rate > 20 breaths/min or PaCO₂ < 32mmHg); white blood cell (WBC) count > 12,000/μL or < 4,000/μL or 10% bands

Definitions.text: Sepsis: Probable or documented infection plus SIRS manifestations

Severe sepsis: Sepsis plus infection-induced organ dysfunction, tissue hypoperfusion, or hypotensionOrgan dysfunction: Altered mental status, generalized edema, acute lung injury, acute renal injury, oliguria, edema, coagulopathy, hyperbilirubinemia, hyperglycemia, ileus, thrombocytopeniaTissue hypoperfusion: Lactate > 1mmol/L, ↓ capillary refill, or mottlingHypotension: Systolic blood pressure (BP) < 90mmHg or mean arterial pressure < 70mmHg
sub_points: Organ dysfunction: Altered mental status, generalized edema, acute lung injury, acute renal injury, oliguria, edema, coagulopathy, hyperbilirubinemia, hyperglycemia, ileus, thrombocytopenia
Tissue hypoperfusion: Lactate > 1mmol/L, ↓ capillary refill, or mottling
Hypotension: Systolic blood pressure (BP) < 90mmHg or mean arterial pressure < 70mmHg

Definitions.text: Septic shock: Sepsis plus hypotension persisting despite administration of adequate fluid resuscitation
Stigmata of shock: Nonspecific pathologic findings reflecting pattern of organ injury due to tissue hypoperfusion

Causes of Shock.text: Hypovolemic: Massive loss of blood or plasma volumee.g., hemorrhage, burns, massive vomiting or diarrhea, anaphylaxis
sub_points: e.g., hemorrhage, burns, massive vomiting or diarrhea, anaphylaxis

Causes of Shock.text: Cardiogenic: Inability of heart to pump blood due to intrinsic failure (e.g., infarction, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathy) or external factors (e.g., cardiac tamponade, pulmonary embolism, tension pneumothorax)

Pathogenesis of Shock.text: Initial phase: ↓ tissue perfusion → sympathetic nervous system activation → ↑ HR, ↑ myocardial contractility, ↑ arterial & venous tone; activation of renin-angiotensin system → BP maintained with blood preferentially shunted to heart & brain

Progressive phase: ↓ BP & tissue perfusion → global tissue hypoxia, ↑ lactic acid, ↓ pH → arteriolar dilation, venous constriction, ↑ capillary permeability → loss of intravascular volume → organ dysfunction
Irreversible phase: Refractory hypotension, multiple system organ failure, and death

Causes of SIRS.text: Overwhelming microbial infection or release of microbial toxinsDeaths due to sepsis: Gram negative bacteria > Gram positive bacteria > fungal >> opportunistic bacteria & fungi, viruses
sub_points: Deaths due to sepsis: Gram negative bacteria > Gram positive bacteria > fungal >> opportunistic bacteria & fungi, viruses

Causes of SIRS.text: Tissue injury: Massive trauma, severe burns, surgery, ischemia/reperfusion injury, transplant rejection, pancreatitis, erythroderma
Metabolic: Thyroid storm, acute adrenal insufficiency
Therapy related: Blood products, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, anesthesia-related malignant hyperpyrexia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, opiates, benzodiazepines

Predisposing Factors to SIRS.text: Inherited or acquired defects in innate or adaptive immune system

Pathogenesis of SIRS.text: Systemic activation of innate immune responseActivation of neutrophils, monocytes/macrophages, & endotheliumEarly phase: Excessive pro-inflammatory cytokines release → vasodilation, edemaLate phase: Diminished innate immune function → diminished adaptive immune functionPro-oxidant state: ↑ reactive oxygen & nitrogen species, ↓ free radical scavengers → vasodilation, edemaPro-coagulation state: Complement, coagulation cascade, & endothelial activation  → disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)→ metabolic derangements, organ dysfunction, and shock
sub_points: Activation of neutrophils, monocytes/macrophages, & endotheliumEarly phase: Excessive pro-inflammatory cytokines release → vasodilation, edemaLate phase: Diminished innate immune function → diminished adaptive immune function
Early phase: Excessive pro-inflammatory cytokines release → vasodilation, edema
Late phase: Diminished innate immune function → diminished adaptive immune function
Pro-oxidant state: ↑ reactive oxygen & nitrogen species, ↓ free radical scavengers → vasodilation, edema
Pro-coagulation state: Complement, coagulation cascade, & endothelial activation  → disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
→ metabolic derangements, organ dysfunction, and shock

Epidemiology.text: SIRS: Most critically ill patients meet criteria
Sepsis: Most common cause of death in noncoronary intensive care unit (ICU)600,000 cases annually in USAIncidence and number of deaths increasing in USA and worldwide
sub_points: 600,000 cases annually in USA
Incidence and number of deaths increasing in USA and worldwide

Presentation.text: Shock: Varies with etiology; most common clinical manifestations are hypotension, tachycardia, cyanosis, and evidence of organ dysfunction
Sepsis: Most common primary sites of infection (in ↓ frequency) are lung, bloodstream, abdomen, skin and soft tissue, urinary tract, and central nervous system

Treatment.text: Shock: Identify and treat underlying cause
Sepsis: Supportive therapy only

Prognosis.text: Mortality rate of shock: Varies according to severity and etiology
Mortality rate of sepsis:Average: 20-30%; range: 5-50%Varies according to predisposing factors, degree of organ dysfunction, type and site of infectious agent
sub_points: Average: 20-30%; range: 5-50%
Varies according to predisposing factors, degree of organ dysfunction, type and site of infectious agent

Clinical Organ Dysfunction Scoring Syste.text: Commonly used scoring systems for assessing severity of illness and predicting mortality in ICU patientsGeneral prognostication scores: Acute physiology and chronic health evaluation (APACHE), simplified acute physiology score (SAPS), mortality probability models (MPM)Organ dysfunction scores: Sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA), multiple organ dysfunction score (MODS), logistic organ dysfunction system (LODS)
sub_points: General prognostication scores: Acute physiology and chronic health evaluation (APACHE), simplified acute physiology score (SAPS), mortality probability models (MPM)
Organ dysfunction scores: Sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA), multiple organ dysfunction score (MODS), logistic organ dysfunction system (LODS)

Other: Evidence of specific underlying cause of shock &/or sepsis

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Alzheimer: Plaque frequency does not correlate well with clinical dementia, but tangle frequency and distribution does
Parkinson: Most of the loss of pigmented neurons in pars compacta of substantia nigra occurs laterally and ventrally, whereas in normal aging, what loss there is occurs medially and dorsally

Alzheimer Disease (AD).text: Most common neurodegenerative disease, incidence ↑ with age

Tauopathies.text: AD, Pick disease, corticobasal degeneration (CBD), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), argyrophilic grain disease

Frontotemporal Dementias (FTD).text: Pick disease, FTD with inclusions (positive for tdp-43, neurofilament, fused in sarcoma protein [FUS], p62, ubiquitin)

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) With.text: Spectrum from ALS only to ALS with frontotemporal dementia to pure frontotemporal dementia with ubiquitin positive inclusions

Synucleinopathies.text: Parkinson disease (PD), Lewy body dementia (LBD), multisystem atrophy (MSA)

Other Heritable Conditions.text: Huntington disease (HD), spinocerebellar ataxias, Friedrich ataxia, inherited amyloidoses

Other Acquired Conditions.text: Acquired-B12 deficiency, chronic traumatic encephalopathy, Wernicke-Korsakoff

Definitions.text: Genetic syndrome resulting from germline mutations inNF1gene encoding for neurofibromin

Incidence.text: ~ 1 in 2,500-3,000 births (1 of the most common inherited syndromes)

NF1Gene.text: Ubiquitously expressed, but levels highest in nervous system

NF1Gene.text: Mosaicism or "segmental" neurofibromatosis manifests as involvement of an isolated anatomical region

Diagnostic Criteria.text: Definite TSC: 2 major features or 1 major + 2 minor

Major features: Cortical tuber, subependymal nodule, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (SEGA), facial angiofibroma/forehead plaque, ungual/periungual fibroma, > 3 hypomelanotic macules, Shagreen patch, multiple retinal hamartomas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipoma/lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)

Minor features: White matter migration lines, transmantle cortical dysplasia, retinal patch, hamartomatous rectal polyps, gingival fibroma, dental pits, hypomelanotic clustered skin lesions, bone cysts, renal cysts, nonrenal hamartomas

Nervous System.text: Cortical tubersLocalized cortical areas with abnormal developmentAbnormal lamination, dysmorphic neurons, microcalcificationsGiant/balloon cells: Pale cytoplasm, variably immunoreactive with glial (S100, GFAP) and neuronal markers (synaptophysin, neurofilament)
sub_points: Localized cortical areas with abnormal developmentAbnormal lamination, dysmorphic neurons, microcalcifications
Abnormal lamination, dysmorphic neurons, microcalcifications
Giant/balloon cells: Pale cytoplasm, variably immunoreactive with glial (S100, GFAP) and neuronal markers (synaptophysin, neurofilament)

Nervous System.text: Cortical cytoarchitectural abnormalities may also be present outside tubers
Subependymal nodules ("candle guttering lesions")Giant cells arranged in clusters and fascicles with mixed glial/neuronal phenotype
sub_points: Giant cells arranged in clusters and fascicles with mixed glial/neuronal phenotype

Retinal Hamartoma/Astrocytoma.text: Small lesions involving nerve fiber layer of retina in ~ 50% of TSC patients
Larger lesions may grow and cause retinal detachment

Renal Cysts.text: TSC2/PKD1contiguous gene syndrome: Coexisting TSC and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (severe)

Micronodular Pneumocyte Hyperplasia.text: Small nodules of bland type II pneumocytes

Subependymal Giant Cell Astrocytoma.text: Microcalcifications in a subset, necrosis rare
Pseudorosettes may be present and simulate ependymal neoplasms
Composed of large cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and macronucleoli

Evidence of glial and neuronal differentiation by immunohistochemistry and electron microscopyConsistent S100 expression, GFAP variableVariable expression of synaptophysin, chromogranin, and neurofilament protein
sub_points: Consistent S100 expression, GFAP variable
Variable expression of synaptophysin, chromogranin, and neurofilament protein

Subependymal Giant Cell Astrocytoma.text: Excellent response to mTOR inhibitors in clinical trials

Angiomyolipoma.text: Usually benign, but large tumors associated with risk for life-threatening bleeding
Most common cause of mortality in TSC adult patients
May be classic or epithelioid subtype
May be a cause of LAM
Partial response to mTOR inhibitors in some studies

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis.text: Occurs in 30% of women with tuberous sclerosis
Lung biopsies demonstrate smooth muscle cells involving lymphatics, vessels, airways, and alveolar septa
Majority of cases associated with tuberous sclerosis haveTSC2mutations (rather thanTSC1) and loss of heterozygosity
Loss of heterozygosity inTSC2also frequent in sporadic LAM

Cardiac Rhabdomyoma.text: Most frequent initial imaging finding in TSC patients
May cause cardiac arrhythmias but also may regress with age

Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor.text: Not part of diagnostic criteria, but recognized in rare TSC patients

Terminology.text: Most common congenital hemolytic anemia in Caucasians: Estimated prevalence of 1:2,000
Group of hemolytic anemias characterized by dense, spherically shaped red blood cells without central pallor

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: HS is clinically, biochemically, and genetically heterogeneous~ 75% of cases are AD with 1 parent affectedAnkyrin-1 gene mutation is most common
sub_points: ~ 75% of cases are AD with 1 parent affected
Ankyrin-1 gene mutation is most common

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Defects in membrane proteins ankyrin-1, band 3, β spectrin, α spectrin, or protein 4.2 lead to loss of membrane surface area
Abnormal spherocytes are sequestered and destroyed in spleen
An intact spleen is required for pathophysiological effects of HS

Clinical Issues.text: Evidence of hemolysis with anemia, reticulocytosis, splenomegaly, jaundice, gallstonesMild disease may not be discovered until adulthoodModerate-severe disease: Excellent prognosis after splenectomy, unless complications
sub_points: Mild disease may not be discovered until adulthood
Moderate-severe disease: Excellent prognosis after splenectomy, unless complications

Clinical Issues.text: Diagnose HS if family history, typical clinical features including hemolysis, and increased spherocytes in blood film

sub_points: Flow cytometry for eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) has high predictive value
No single test identifies all cases of HS

Definitions.text: Group of hemolytic anemias characterized by presence of dense, spherically shaped red blood cells without central pallor
Shape abnormality renders erythrocyte susceptible to premature removal by spleen

Red blood cell membrane loss due to defective vertical protein linkages between membrane skeleton and lipid bilayer

Age.text: Majority of individuals experience jaundice at birth with subsequent mild to moderate anemia
If HS is extremely mild, may not be identified until adulthood when exacerbated by infection

Ethnicity.text: Most commonly seen in Northern European, Northern American, and Japanese populations
Least commonly found in African American and southeast Asian populations

Presentation.text: ~ 75% of cases have AD pattern of inheritanceFamily history of anemia, jaundice, gallstones, splenomegaly &/or splenectomy common
sub_points: Family history of anemia, jaundice, gallstones, splenomegaly &/or splenectomy common

Presentation.text: Remaining cases are AR or have de novo mutationsRecessive forms of HS tend to have more severe clinical symptoms
sub_points: Recessive forms of HS tend to have more severe clinical symptoms

Presentation.text: Anemia is most common presenting complaint in childhoodCheck for scleral icterus, jaundice (often intermittent), and splenomegaly
sub_points: Check for scleral icterus, jaundice (often intermittent), and splenomegaly

Presentation.text: Disease severity varies widely as classified below for the non-neonatal period (% of HS patients)Mild (~ 20%): Compensated hemolysis, minimal spherocytosis, minimal anemia, slight reticulocytosis (< 6%), mild splenomegalyModerate (~ 60%): Hemoglobin 8.0-11.0 g/dL, reticulocytes generally > 8%Moderately severe (~ 10%): Hemoglobin 6.0-8.0 g/dL, reticulocytes generally > 15%Severe (3-5%): Transfusions required to maintain hemoglobin > 6.0 g/dL, almost always AR
sub_points: Mild (~ 20%): Compensated hemolysis, minimal spherocytosis, minimal anemia, slight reticulocytosis (< 6%), mild splenomegaly
Moderate (~ 60%): Hemoglobin 8.0-11.0 g/dL, reticulocytes generally > 8%
Moderately severe (~ 10%): Hemoglobin 6.0-8.0 g/dL, reticulocytes generally > 15%
Severe (3-5%): Transfusions required to maintain hemoglobin > 6.0 g/dL, almost always AR

Presentation.text: Some neonates have more severe anemiaUnable to mount an adequate erythropoietic response until > 1 year of age
sub_points: Unable to mount an adequate erythropoietic response until > 1 year of age

Terminology.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI)Inherited disorder of bone fragility resulting from abnormal quantity &/or quality of collagen type I
sub_points: Inherited disorder of bone fragility resulting from abnormal quantity &/or quality of collagen type I

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Most cases are thought to be caused by point mutation affecting glycine residue in eitherCOL1A1orCOL1A2
Collagen type I is a major constituent of bone, dentin, sclerae, ligaments, and skinTherefore, mutations inCOL1Aresult in abnormalities of these structures
sub_points: Therefore, mutations inCOL1Aresult in abnormalities of these structures

Clinical Issues.text: 7 types described, each with a different degree of severity
Bone fragility increases in severity as followsType I < types IV, V, VI, VII < type III < type II
sub_points: Type I < types IV, V, VI, VII < type III < type II

sub_points: Fractures sustained in utero

Short, curved femora with deformity due to multiple fractures

Thin trabeculae with severely deficient ossification
Excessive callus formation at fracture sites

Terminology.text: Autosomal recessive inherited genetic disease resulting from homozygous point mutation (valine to glutamine at codon 6) of β globin gene

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) polymerizes under low oxygen tension, resulting in RBC sickling
RBC sickling and adhesion result in chronic anemia, microinfarcts, and painful vascular crisis
Heterozygous state provides protection againstPlasmodium falciparuminfection

Terminology.text: Disease in which leukocytes cannot eliminate phagocytosed microorganisms, resulting in recurrent infections and granulomas

Clinical Issues.text: Prevalence: 1 in 1 million people; 1 in 250,000 births
Recurrent infections presenting as pneumonia, abscesses, osteomyelitis, and bacteremia
Usually detected by 5 years of age
More common in boys since it is often X-linked
Testing includes nitroblue tetrazolium reduction test, flow cytometry, and others
Antibiotic treatment for active infections as well as prophylactically
Improving prognosisPatients can live until adulthood
sub_points: Patients can live until adulthood

Microscopic Features.text: Necrotizing granulomas with abscesses in white pulp or red pulp
± abscess formation
Organisms may be difficult to identify in spleen

Ancillary Tests.text: Special stains (e.g., Fite, GMS, Brown-Hopp, Warthin-Starry) used to detect organisms

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Bacterial infections and fungal infections show necrotizing granulomas
Other defects in leukocyte function, e.g., Chédiak-Higashi syndrome

Synonyms.text: Bridges–Good syndrome, Quie syndrome, fatal granulomatosis of childhood

Definitions.text: Genetically determined enzymatic deficiency in a component of phagocyte NADPH oxidase characterized by impaired destruction of phagocytosed microorganismsPhagocytes in CGD patients engulf microorganisms but cannot destroy them, because they do not activate oxygen-dependent killing mechanismsPatients cannot form reactive oxygen compoundsMicroorganisms are surrounded by macrophages, forming granulomas
sub_points: Phagocytes in CGD patients engulf microorganisms but cannot destroy them, because they do not activate oxygen-dependent killing mechanismsPatients cannot form reactive oxygen compoundsMicroorganisms are surrounded by macrophages, forming granulomas
Patients cannot form reactive oxygen compounds
Microorganisms are surrounded by macrophages, forming granulomas

Defective Phagocyte NADPH Oxidase.text: Defect can be in any component of NADPH oxidase
NADPH has membrane-bound componentsgp91-phox, p22-phox, rap1a
sub_points: gp91-phox, p22-phox, rap1a

Defective Phagocyte NADPH Oxidase.text: NADPH has cytoplasmic componentsp47-phox, p40-phox, p67-phox, rac2
sub_points: p47-phox, p40-phox, p67-phox, rac2

Defective Phagocyte NADPH Oxidase.text: Mutations can be deletions, frame shift, nonsense, and missense
~ 65% of patients have defect in gp91-phox, which presents as X-linked disease
~ 35% of patients have cytoplasmic component defect, which presents as autosomal recessive defectMost common autosomal recessive defect is in p47-phox
sub_points: Most common autosomal recessive defect is in p47-phox

Defective Phagocyte NADPH Oxidase.text: Low levels of NADPH can also cause CGDWomen homozygous for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD) can have decreased NADPH levels
sub_points: Women homozygous for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD) can have decreased NADPH levels

Normal Function of WAS Protein.text: WAS protein also participates in signal transduction pathways, independent of its cytoskeletal function

WASMutations.text: Absence of WAS protein deregulates actin polymerization in hematopoietic cells, resulting in profound immune abnormalities

For inactivating mutations, severity of phenotype may partially depend on type of mutation and effect on residual WAS protein functionMissense mutations leading to expression of full-length, though defective, WAS protein tend to be associated with XLT or attenuated form of WASTruncating mutations or mutations leading to severely decreased expression tend to be associated with more severe WASHowever, direct prediction of phenotype from genotype is difficult

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Important diagnostic clues include heterogeneity of glomerular lesions; "full house" pattern (IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C1q) and TBM deposits of IgG; and endothelial tubuloreticular inclusions and thumbprint pattern in deposits

Definitions.text: Systemic autoimmune disease manifested by inflammation of skin, joints, kidneys, and central nervous system, with pathogenic IgG autoantibodies targeting nuclear, cell surface, and plasma protein self-antigens

IgA Nephropathy.text: IgA-dominant deposits without tubuloreticular inclusions or extraglomerular immune deposits

Terminology.text: Acute demyelinating disease prompting biopsy due to enhancement, prominent surrounding edema, and tumor or abscess-like appearance
Most patients with demyelinating disease prompting biopsy eventually develop relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS)
Disease course in most patients, once MS diagnosis is made by clinical/neuroimaging criteria, similar to that of "ordinary" MS

Inconsistent with pathological diagnosis of grade II infiltrating gliomas

Microscopic.text: Sharp border
Numerous foamy macrophages
Admixed reactive astrocytes with long processes
Loss of myelin on special stains

Periventricular, perivenular location typical

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Members of MTB complex are rod-shaped, acid-fast, aerobic, slow-growing intracellular pathogens that subvert phagosomal cells in order to persist and evade immune system
Humans are the only natural reservoir for mycobacterial speciesM. tuberculosis,M. africanum, andM. canetti
Most common in developing world
Drug resistance is a serious problem and some infections are virtually untreatable
Transmission is mainly by inhalation of contaminated droplets, thoughM. bovisinfection can be transmitted from cattle via undercooked meat or unpasteurized milk
May establish itself in a subclinical, latent state, or immediately progress to active disease (~ 10%)
Latent disease may reactivate in old age, in periods of stress or nutrient deprivation, or upon immunosuppression or HIV infection
Pulmonary tuberculosis is most common manifestationUsually presents with nonspecific constitutional symptoms and productive cough
sub_points: Usually presents with nonspecific constitutional symptoms and productive cough

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Extrapulmonary tuberculosis can affect virtually any organ system and result from contiguous or lymphohematogenous spread
Histopathologic hallmark is a necrotizing granuloma with giant cells and epithelioid histiocytes

Definitions.text: Greek: "Myco" (fungi, for similarity of mycobacteria to fungal growth on liquid media surfaces)
Latin: "Tuber" (lump or swelling)

Environmental Exposure.text: Humans are the only natural reservoir for mycobacterial speciesM. tuberculosis,Mycobacterium africanum, andMycobacterium canetti
Most common in developing world

Terminology.text: Autoimmune disease characterized by diffuse goiter, thyrotoxicosis, infiltrative ophthalmopathy, and occasionally infiltrative dermopathology

Clinical Issues.text: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism in USA
Most common cause of spontaneous hyperthyroidism in patients younger than 40
Female to male ratio of 8:1
Diffuse goiter with thyrotoxicosis, eye disease, and possible skin manifestations
TSH receptor antibody is most specific for Graves disease, however, these may be seen in other thyroiditides such as Hashimoto
Strongly associated with haplotypes HLA-B8 and HLA-DR3
Prognosis is good with treatment, however if left untreated patients may develop thyroid storm, which can be deadly

Macroscopic Features.text: Diffuse symmetric enlargement
Beefy, deep red parenchyma
Prominent vascular pattern

Microscopic Features.text: Preserved follicular architecture with prominent stromal vessels and hyperplasia of tall columnar cells in the follicle
Iodine treatment may diminish vascularity of the gland, causing involution of the follicle, causing follicular cells to be cuboidal rather than columnar

Definitions.text: Autoimmune disease characterized by diffuse goiter, thyrotoxicosis, infiltrative ophthalmopathy, and occasionally infiltrative dermopathology
Named after Irish clinician Robert Graves, who described a syndrome of cardiac palpitations, thyroid enlargement, and exophthalmos in 1835

Environmental Exposure.text: Iodine replacement in previously deficient patients can cause a reactive hyperthyroid state and unmask an underlying autoimmune process
Smoking increases risk of Graves 2-3x and is significantly associated with ophthalmopathy

General.text: Stronger familial predisposition than Hashimoto (monozygotic twin concordance rate may be as high as 60%)
Strongly associated with haplotypes HLA-B8 and HLA-DR3

Hyperthyroidism is caused by antibodiesAntibodies directed toward extracellular domain of thyroid stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) on follicular cellsSerum of patient with Graves disease has been found to stimulate thyroid activity in animals in controlled experimentThese antibodies activate receptor and stimulate hormone synthesis and secretion as well as proliferation of follicular cells
sub_points: Antibodies directed toward extracellular domain of thyroid stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) on follicular cellsSerum of patient with Graves disease has been found to stimulate thyroid activity in animals in controlled experimentThese antibodies activate receptor and stimulate hormone synthesis and secretion as well as proliferation of follicular cells

These antibodies activate receptor and stimulate hormone synthesis and secretion as well as proliferation of follicular cells

General.text: Possible triggers include infectious etiology as well as physiological and psychological stressTriggered disturbance of immune system confers an imbalance that begets autoimmunity
sub_points: Triggered disturbance of immune system confers an imbalance that begets autoimmunity

General.text: Role of gonadal steroids has been suggested because of higher incidence in women, particularly in times of hormonal change such as puberty, pregnancy, and menopause6x increased risk of Graves disease in postpartum women
sub_points: 6x increased risk of Graves disease in postpartum women

General.text: In men, Graves disease occurs later in life with more severe symptoms and greater incidence of ophthalmopathy
Autoimmunity is triggered by genetic susceptibility and environmental factors

Ophthalmopathy.text: Thought to be related to expression of HLA class II antigens by orbital muscles, to which activated T cells react
TSH receptor mRNA has been detected in retroorbital fibroblasts

Dermopathy.text: Thought to be a mechanism involving fibroblasts in skin, similar to that of Graves ophthalmopathy

Incidence.text: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism in USA
Most common cause of spontaneous hyperthyroidism in patients younger than 40
One of the most common autoimmune diseasesAnnual incidence is 20-25 per 100,000
sub_points: Annual incidence is 20-25 per 100,000

Age.text: Usually presents in 3rd or 4th decade of life

Presentation.text: Diffuse goiter with thyrotoxicosis, eye disease, and possible skin manifestations
Most common symptoms include anxiety, hyperhydrosis, heat intolerance, palpitations, fatigue, tachycardia, muscle wasting, and weight loss
Patients have goiter, tachycardia, tremors, and warm, moist skin
Exophthalmos may be present
Usually presents at later age in men and with more severe symptoms
Often presents in women undergoing states of hormonal changes such as pregnancy or menopause
Increased radioiodine uptake on imaging

Laboratory Tests.text: Serum antibodies against thyroid peroxidase or microsomal antibodies, thyroglobulin, and TSH receptor
TSH receptor antibody is most specific for Graves disease, however these may be seen in other thyroiditides such as Hashimoto
Strongly associated with haplotypes HLA-B8 and HLA-DR3
Patients have diminished levels of circulating CD8 T cells

Surgical approaches.text: Thyroidectomy

sub_points: Inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis through interference with peroxidase-mediated iodination of tyrosine residues

Treatment Effects.text: Hyperplastic effects are diminished and regressed but are still present

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.text: Graves disease may have papillary structures with fibrovascular cores and psammoma bodies

Look closely for nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma in these instances, and always consider clinical history
Papillary thyroid carcinoma can be found in 1-4% of cases

Hashimoto Thyroiditis.text: Distinction from early Hashimoto may be difficult clinically as Hashimoto may present initially with hypothyroid symptoms
However, Hashimoto will inevitably convert to hypothyroid symptoms
Autoantibody panel may be similar, but TSH is more specific for Graves
Hashimoto will have more prominent oncocytic metaplasia
More lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal centers
Fibrous bands coursing through parenchyma favors diagnosis of Hashimoto over Graves

Toxic Multinodular Goiter.text: Majority of gland with follicles having abundant colloid
Patients will be hyperthyroidCharacteristic antibody panel of Graves will be absent
sub_points: Characteristic antibody panel of Graves will be absent

Adenomatous Nodule.text: Nodules of multiple sizes with background of normal-appearing thyroid

Dyshormonogenetic Goiter.text: Family history is often identified, as this is an inherited disorder

Terminology.text: Morphea is mainly limited to skin and subcutaneous tissue and, occasionally, underlying muscle and bone

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Presumably, microvascular injury in the genetically predisposed launches cytokine-driven profibrotic cascade following an environmental trigger

Clinical Issues.text: Classified into 5 subtypes with varying clinical presentations (extracutaneous findings possible)
May cause physical deformity (e.g., muscular atrophy, joint contractures, and limb length discrepancies)

Macroscopic Features.text: Smooth, indurated plaques with variable postinflammatory pigmentary alteration

Microscopic Features.text: Early superficial and deep perivascular predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate
Obliterative sclerotic dermal collagen bundles follow resolution of inflammation

Definitions.text: Most common form of scleroderma (group of fibrosing disorders that result in an imbalance between collagen production and destruction) in childhoodClinically heterogeneous disease process that is predominantly localized to the skin and subcutaneous tissues with possible involvement of underlying muscle and boneImportant to note: Numerous extracutaneous features are now recognized to be a part of JLS

Multifactorial.text: GeneticAutoimmunity and microchimerism may play a role
sub_points: Autoimmunity and microchimerism may play a role

Incidence.text: Relatively rare pediatric malady; however, the most common connective tissue disease of childhood

Gender.text: Mild female predilection with a female to male ratio of 2.4:1

Such a limitation may not be of great consequence given the relatively low prevalence of the latter in patients < 16 years of age
At time of diagnosis, children usually have significantly less frequent visceral involvement than adults

Arthritis and myositis are more common in children than in adults, but Raynaud phenomenon, skin necrosis, interstitial lung disease, gastroesophageal dysmotility, renal involvement, and arterial hypertension are less common in children

Treatment.text: Due to the relative rarity and self-limiting tendency of JLS, most data on treatment have been extrapolated from studies on adult patients
Level of functional &/or cosmetic deformity is weighed against the toxicity of therapy
No single therapy has shown absolute benefit in children with JLS or JSS, and treatment must be modified according to the stage of the lesion
Physiotherapy, anti-inflammatories, vitamin D analogues, and UV irradiation have been the focus in the treatment of localized disease
Treatment of more advanced disease mainly includes antifibrotics, immunosuppressants, and vasodilators

Prognosis.text: JLS is typically self-limited, with an initial inflammatory stage that is followed by a period of stabilization and, ultimately, resolutionAverage duration of disease is ~ 3-5 years, but much longer disease activity has been reportedProlonged activity is usually associated with deep variants of circumscribed morphea and linear sclerodermaSignificant disfigurement and disability can result
sub_points: Average duration of disease is ~ 3-5 years, but much longer disease activity has been reported
Prolonged activity is usually associated with deep variants of circumscribed morphea and linear scleroderma
Significant disfigurement and disability can result

Prognosis.text: JSS has a better prognosis than its adult counterpart, with less severe organ involvement and better long-term survival

General Features.text: Skin lesions typically present with an inflammatory stage characterized by erythematous patches and plaques
With resolution of inflammation, cutaneous lesions develop a white, sclerotic center and violaceous peripheral border ("lilac ring")
Adnexal structures are eventually destroyed by excess collagen deposition resulting in smooth, indurated plaques with variable postinflammatory hyperpigmentation

Histologic Features.text: In early lesionsReticular dermis shows a predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate with occasional plasma cells and eosinophils in a superficial and deep perivascular patternEndothelial cells may seem swollenThickening of collagen bundles may be appreciated
sub_points: Reticular dermis shows a predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate with occasional plasma cells and eosinophils in a superficial and deep perivascular pattern
Endothelial cells may seem swollen
Thickening of collagen bundles may be appreciated

Histologic Features.text: In developed lesionsNotable inflammatory infiltrate is no longer seenCollagen bundles are prominently eosinophilic, thickened, and crowdedHypertrophic collagen bundles replace adipose tissue surrounding eccrine glands and pilosebaceous units, both of which appear entrapped and atrophicDermal blood vessels are similarly scarceAdipose tissue of subcutis appears entrapped within dermis as collagen bundles extend deep
sub_points: Notable inflammatory infiltrate is no longer seen

Serologic Testing.text: ~ 42% of children with JLS have been shown to harbor antinuclear antibodies
Rheumatoid factor is seen in low titers in ~ 16% of JLS patients and has significant correlation with arthritisSignificant correlation with arthritis
sub_points: Significant correlation with arthritis

Serologic Testing.text: ~ 2-3% of those with JLS have anti-topoisomerase I antibodies (anti-Scl 70)
Nearly 2% of pediatric JLS patients have anticentromere antibodies

Systemic Scleroderma.text: Cannot be differentiated from morphea on histopathology alone

Scleredema.text: Interfibrous spaces containing mucopolysaccharides are seen among hypertrophied collagen bundles
Inflammation is not a significant component of the histopathology at any stage of the lesion

Graft-vs.-Host Disease (GVHD), Scleroder.text: Involvement of papillary and upper reticular dermis typically seen at an earlier stage

Scleromyxedema.text: Prominent mucin deposition in upper and mid-reticular dermis

Radiation Dermatitis.text: Clinical examination reveals presence of surface changes (xerosis, scale, hyperkeratosis, and telangiectasias) and absence of violaceous ring
Atypical radiation cells, radiation-induced elastosis, and dilated superficial vessels characterize histopathology

Nephrogenic Fibrosing Dermopathy.text: Histopathology identical to that of scleromyxedema

Lichen Sclerosus Et Atrophicus.text: Considered a variant of morphea by some
Sclerosis is limited to papillary dermis, with a band-like lymphoid infiltrate present between sclerotic and nonsclerotic areas

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Extracutaneous organ impairment is mild and not life-threatening in comparison to that seen in JSSMany believe the 2 disease processes represent opposite ends of a continuous spectrum
sub_points: Many believe the 2 disease processes represent opposite ends of a continuous spectrum

Pathogenesis.text: Amyloidogenic proteins have antiparallel, β-pleated sheet tertiary structure (also termed cross β-sheets)Structure determined by x-ray diffraction, which shows 2 reflections: Sharp one at ~ 4.7 Å & more diffuse one at ~ 8-12 ÅCross-β motif forms central structural spine of amyloid protofilamentsStructure accounts for Congo red staining & apple-green birefringence under polarized light since it enables anisotropic binding of Congo red moleculesResistance to metabolic processing leads to accumulation & interference with physiologic functioning
