Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Hepatotropic viruses: Hepatitis A, B, C, D, and E
Herpes virus group: HSV, CMV, EBV, VZV, HHV-6
Viral hemorrhagic fevers: Yellow fever, dengue fever, Ebola, hantavirus, etc.

Clinical Issues.text: Important elements of chart review: Travel, food consumption, and sexual history, history of injection drug use, blood transfusions, tattoos/piercings, blood/body fluid exposures, immunosuppression

Macroscopic Features.text: Acute hepatitis: Hepatomegaly, cholestasis, necrosis, regenerative nodules, hemorrhage
Chronic hepatitis: Hepatomegaly or atrophy, cirrhosis, masses

Microscopic Features.text: Acute hepatitis (HAV, HBV ± HDV, HCV, HEV): Lobular inflammation, acidophil bodies, variable necrosis, swollen hepatocytes, lobular disarray, cholestasis, variable portal inflammation
Chronic hepatitis (HBV ± HDV, HCV, rarely HEV): Portal inflammation, variable interface and lobular activity, fibrosis, cirrhosis, ± siderosis, dysplastic nodules, hepatocellular carcinoma

Reporting Considerations.text: Final report should include: Type of viral hepatitis, extent of hepatic disease, associated extrahepatic findings, whether the virus was the cause of death or a contributing factor

Characteristics.text: Gram-negative, microaerophilic curved bacterium with flagella

Culture.text: Indicated if patient fails basic triple regimen therapy for eradication of organism (drug resistance)
Homogenized stomach biopsies are plated onto trypticase soy sheep blood agar and incubated at 5-7% oxygen/5% carbon dioxide at 35 °C (growth within 2-4 days)
Antibiotic susceptibility testing is performed using a battery of antibiotics to determine resistance and select additional treatment

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Members of MTB complex are rod-shaped, acid-fast, aerobic, slow-growing intracellular pathogens that subvert phagosomal cells in order to persist and evade immune system
Humans are the only natural reservoir for mycobacterial speciesM. tuberculosis,M. africanum, andM. canetti
Most common in developing world
Drug resistance is a serious problem and some infections are virtually untreatable
Transmission is mainly by inhalation of contaminated droplets, thoughM. bovisinfection can be transmitted from cattle via undercooked meat or unpasteurized milk
May establish itself in a subclinical, latent state, or immediately progress to active disease (~ 10%)
Latent disease may reactivate in old age, in periods of stress or nutrient deprivation, or upon immunosuppression or HIV infection
Pulmonary tuberculosis is most common manifestationUsually presents with nonspecific constitutional symptoms and productive cough
sub_points: Usually presents with nonspecific constitutional symptoms and productive cough

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Extrapulmonary tuberculosis can affect virtually any organ system and result from contiguous or lymphohematogenous spread
Histopathologic hallmark is a necrotizing granuloma with giant cells and epithelioid histiocytes

Terminology.text: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by bacteriaTreponema pallidum
Pathologic treponematoses: Venereal syphilis (T. pallidum), yaws (T. pertenue), bejel (T. endemicum), pinta (T. carateum)

Clinical Issues.text: Primary: Single small, red, painless papule with ulceration (chancre)
Secondary: Widespread skin rash; mainly affect soles and palms but can spread to whole body
Tertiary: Solitary lesion (gummas)

Microscopic Features.text: Primary: Acanthotic epidermis, ulceration, endothelial swelling, and dense lymphoplasmacytic response
Secondary: Cellular infiltrate consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages, some neutrophils, epithelioid cells, and occasional giant cells
Tertiary: Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Psoriasis, drug reaction, and lichenoid hypersensitivity reaction

Synonyms.text: Venereal syphilis (Treponema pallidum pallidum), yaws (Treponema pallidum pertenue), bejel (Treponema pallidum endemicum), pinta (Treponema pallidum carateum)

Cryptococcosis.text: Narrow-based budding pleomorphic yeast forms (4-10 µm in diameter)

Epidemiology.text: 1/3 of those in developing countries have been infected

Presentation.text: Incubation period of 1-3 weeks between ingestion of cysts and onset of symptoms

sub_points: Cysts are infectious and can survive in environment for prolonged periods of time
Following ingestion, trophozoites excyst in small intestine and attach to mucosal surface via ventral sucking disk
Trophozoites re-encyst in large intestine and are shed as cysts, hence relatively low ratio of trophozoites to cysts in feces

Parasite Features.text: Trophozoites attach to duodenal and jejunal mucosal surface but do not invade mucosa
Diarrhea is thought to result from a combination of malabsorption and hypersecretion in small intestine
Cysts are oval (11-14 μm), contain 4 nuclei, 4 axonemes, and 4 median bodies
Trophozoites are pear-shaped (10-20 μm), contain 2 nuclei, a sucking disk, 4 pairs of flagella, 2 axonemes, and 2 median bodies
Can be subdivided into 7 distinct genetic assemblages (A-G) based on molecular characteristics
As few as 10 cysts are sufficient to cause infection

Histologic Features.text: Organisms are seen on surface of mucosa as purple to pink bodies with a tapered end

Changes in mucosa may be subtle to severe (depending on chronicity)Rarely see villous atrophyIncreased crypt depth with shortening of microvilliBiopsies are commonly done in cases of diarrhea to rule out other possible causes of symptoms
sub_points: Rarely see villous atrophy
Increased crypt depth with shortening of microvilli
Biopsies are commonly done in cases of diarrhea to rule out other possible causes of symptoms

Histologic Features.text: Trichrome stain will highlight organisms

Immunofluorescence.text: Direct fluorescent antibody testing of feces

Stool Examination.text: Light microscopic exam for morphological detectionCysts &/or trophozoites are visible on fresh smear (saline suspension of feces)Formalin preparation for permanent staining
sub_points: Cysts &/or trophozoites are visible on fresh smear (saline suspension of feces)
Formalin preparation for permanent staining

Stool Examination.text: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for antigen detection
Immunochromatographic assay for antigen detection (rapid test)

Infectious.text: Amebiasis, viral gastroenteritis, cryptosporidiosis, strongyloidiasisDifferentiate based on morphological ova and parasite examination of stool and antibody testing
sub_points: Differentiate based on morphological ova and parasite examination of stool and antibody testing

Noninfectious.text: Irritable bowel syndrome lacks mucosal abnormalities on biopsy
Celiac disease (severe villous atrophy, hyperplastic crypts, lymphocytic infiltrate, and plasma cells in lamina propria)
Cystic fibrosis (chloride sweat test and genetic testing)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Consider giardiasis in setting of diarrhea with steatorrhea of > 1 week duration
